clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluating the Effect of Acupuncture on Pain Relief Using Quantitative Sensory Testing (QST)
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluating the Effect of Acupuncture on Pain Relief Using QST

collaborator.agency: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health (NCCIH)

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to explore a new approach in assessing the effectiveness of acupuncture therapy in the treatment chronic pain conditions.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in QST measures in response to acupuncture
primary_outcome.description: Changes in response to heat stimulation stated as pain, sensitivity and tolerance. Responses are measured with a quantitative sensory testing (QST) device. Measurements are taken before, during, and after acupunture treatment.

arm_group.description: Patients with radicular pain receiving acupuncture (Group 1), sham acupuncture (Group 2), or neither acupuncture nor sham acupuncture (Group 3);
Healthy subjects (no pain) receiving acupuncture (Group 4), sham acupuncture (Group 5), neither acupuncture nor sham acupuncture (Group 6).

intervention.description: Patients with radicular pain receiving acupuncture (Group 1), sham acupuncture (Group 2), or neither acupuncture nor sham acupuncture (Group 3);
Healthy subjects (no pain) receiving acupuncture (Group 4), sham acupuncture (Group 5), neither acupuncture nor sham acupuncture (Group 6).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Subject will be between ages 18 to 65 years. Both male and female subjects will be recruited.
2. Subject should have had cervical or lumbar radicular pain for at least two months. This requirement is to avoid the uncertainty of an unstable pain condition and to minimize the study variation.
3. Subject has a pain score of 4 or above (visual analog scale, VAS: 0 - 10 from no pain to worst pain).
4. Cervical or lumbar radicular pain will include, but is not limited to, such clinical conditions as disk herniation, spinal stenosis, and post-laminectomy syndrome.
5. For controls, healthy subjects without radicular pain for at least three months will be recruited. *We are no longer accepting healthy volunteers.*
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Subject has detectable sensory deficits at the site of QST. Sensory deficits refer to such conditions resulting from neurological diseases or medical conditions causing peripheral polyneuropathy and sensory changes, which include but are not limited to diabetic neuropathy, alcoholic neuropathy, AIDS neuropathy, severe thyroid disease, and severe liver or kidney disorders.
2. Subject has scar tissue, infection, or acute injury at the site of QST.
3. Subject is on anticoagulation therapy.
4. Subject is pregnant.
5. Subject is tested positive on illicit drugs.
